messageBody:
thanks for your answers!

A few people here refer to maven as their library management tool. So
far I thought of maven as a extension to ant. Could somebody give me a
hint how JUnit is installed with maven?

ben



--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, BÃ¶hm, Martin <martin.boehm@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
>
> I'm using JUnit on windows systems. The several
> Java-RTs und SDKs I usually install on
>
> %program files%\java
> \j2rt1.4
> \j2se1.4.2
> \jdk1.5
> \jdk1.6
> \j2me
>
> For the default java runtime I use 1.6 and set it
> to JAVA_HOME=%program files%\java\jdk1.6
>
> For libraries I usually use maven. So its very
> simple to set references to any library. I set it
> to PATH=%PATH%,C:\mvnrepos
>
> In special cases I also use a separate lib
> directory. Its a remainder of the time before I
> used Maven. But its rather obsolete if you have
> access to a global maven repository.
>
> Running the tests I also use Maven, so calling
> "mvn test" runs all my tests and on the other hand
> using patterns like "mvn test Dtest=*ServiceTest"
> runs only the service tests as well.
>
> Nevertheless I set the maven install directory
> to the PATH variable to call it quickly from
> any project location.
>
> Sounds like a promotion for maven, but it really
> simplifies my tasks.
>
> Regards,
> Martin
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> > Behalf Of ben.aurel
> > Sent: Samstag, 10. Mai 2008 13:55
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit] where lives your junit stuff
> >
> > hi
> >
> > I have some another basic questions on my quest for a "professional"
> > java environment with JUnit...
> >
> > I'm working on Mac OS X and I try to find out how experiences
> > java folks organize their Java development environment. It
> > breaks down to the following 4 questions:
> >
> > 1. Basic JDK Installation
> > --------------------------
> > After downloading the jdk.zip file from SUN, where do you put
> > those contents?
> > WIN: C:\jse5, (others ?)
> > MAC: standard install path is /Library/Java/Home (do the mac
> > guys leave it this way, or are there arguments against that path?)
> > NIX: ?
> >
> > 2. Java Libraries like JUnit
> > ----------------------------
> > where to put 3rd party libraries?
> >
> > WIN: ?
> > MAC: /Developer/Java, ~/Library/Java/, ... ?
> > NIX: ?
> >
> > 3. Environment Settings for JUnit in .bash_profile
> > --------------------------------------------------
> >
> > I think this is the right way to do it:
> >
> > export JUNIT_HOME="/Developer/jlibs/junit"
> > PATH=$PATH:$JYTHON_HOME:$JUNIT_HOME
> >
> > export CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:$JUNIT_HOME/junit-4.4.jar:$JUNIT_HOME
> >
> > but why do I need
> > $JUNIT_HOME/junit-4.4.jar
> > and
> > $JUNIT_HOME
> > in the classpath?
> >
> > 4. wrapper for running junit
> > ------------------------------
> >
> > is there no better way to run junit then with commands like
> >
> > $ java org.junit.runner.JUnitCore ...
> >
> > do you write command wrappers and how?
> >
> > thanks a lot for your answers
> >
> > Ben
>
